title: Property Price Growth Remains Stagnant in the U.K.
text:
Property price growth was close to non-existent across the U.K. in October, according to a report Tuesday from Nationwide.



On an annual basis, values ticked up 0.4%, marking the 11th consecutive month that annual price growth failed to break past 1%, the bank and mortgage provider said.



More: An 11-Villa Estate in Italy That Dates Back to the 11th Century

The 0.4% annual jump equated to a roughly £800 (US$1,028) increase in value, a significant slowing compared with previous years. In October 2016, for example, prices increased by £9,100 across the year.



The average price of a home in the U.K. is now £215,368.



The pace of growth has slowed in the face of weaker global growth and intensifying Brexit uncertainty, the report said.



Brexit had been scheduled for Oct. 31, until Monday, and which point it was announced that the deadline had been extended again, until Jan. 31, 2020.



From Penta: Future Returns: Real Estate Remains a Good Bet in Some Hong Kong Sectors

“Much like the walking dead, the U.K. property market continues to plod on through the thick fog of Brexit uncertainty, showing little signs of resurrection to former levels,” said Shepherd Ncube, founder and CEO of estate agency Springbok Properties, in a statement in response to the report.



“However, like a proverbial Michael Myers of ‘Halloween’ movie notoriety, it is still refusing to actually die, and while current price growth may seem insignificant, we are still in a better position than we were this time last year,” he said.
